comments.commentBody: Already donated. Hope they are going to bring in cybersecurity experts to look at the Diebold voting machines to see if they were hacked.

Give the ya-hoos their president and let them see what they got.  I'm tired of battling those who don't read between the lines and vote for reality TV to rule the country.  Let them see what it got them.  We are not going to be able to battle this, so we might as well enjoy revenge of sorts as their eyes get opened on everything from jobs, impossible to get back, to money flying up their chimney to the rich and out their pockets and hey, if you actually got immigrants deported, go send your kids to pick lettuce and clean toilets ad do all the dirty work you think you're too good for while somebody eyes your daughter's neither parts to grab.
I'm with you there. I have morons in my circle who believe there life will grt better, when their tormentors actually are their Repugnant overlords.

I agree that the potential for very negative outcomes for Trump voters is very real.  But I don't think they will get it.  They will stick to their guy.  They will NEVER admit that they were conned - it is just too difficult.  They will keep following him on twitter, watching him on youtube.  Anything that goes wrong, he will blame on the usual suspects and they will cheer him on.  Income inequality will just grow but this will further reinforce the current tide towards blaming "the other."  We are on a dangerous path and we may never get off of it.

I love how super liberals like illegal immigrants to do things like pick their lettuce. They dont realize at all that there are a ton of boomers who cant retire that are now agricultural pickers. They dont realize that legal immigrants wish they could get paid more to pick lettuce. They dont realize that illegal immigrants do their drywall, a job that used to get paid $25/hr but now pays $10. They dont realize that illegal immigrants are doing their carpentry, and that there are many legal immigrant and citizen carpenters that have been put out of buisiness.

They want people to have higher wages and protection from exploitation, but then want to make sure we have illegal immigrants to pick their lettuce so their Whole Foods bill doesnt become even more astronomical.

I find it confusing to day the least, and at the most hypocritical.
Make it !,450,000 and counting. Another $1M is needed to pay recount fees for all Pennsylvania, Michigan and Wisconsin

We're not living in a Comey- Russian Republic. It's a great tag-line & you received 122 clicks & counting. The big question is do the politicians in Washington D.C. particularly the Democrat's have the stomach to demand a recount. So far I've seen none. I get the feeling the establishment on either side doesn't want a recount to happen no matter what Jill Stein does.
Because people vote in all sorts of ways (early voting, absentee ballot, etc.) and ballots needs to be verified and certified.
Typical Trump:  always says that someone else is doing something wrong and it turns out its something he had done.  One has to believe the opposite of whatever he says is the truth.

I do believe it's the Republicans and or white, male Democrats  from the rust belt who need to "look for a job!".  It's they who decided they needed more help from the government to get them (the jobs) back from overseas.   Let's not confuse who was doing the asking.

4 years ago, there was a presidential candidate who said that Russia was the number one enemy of the state, and, that on day one he would set up a cyber security work force. He was laughed at and  ridiculed. Sounds like Karma biting a lot of people in the rear.
It's very clear the election was stolen.
Sure felt that way in the primary - DNC and Super Delegates.
No, it is not!

It's very clear the election was stolen.

Yes you're right the DNC cheated Sanders who if given a fair chance by the all Hillary and Trump media would have beaten Trum p but instead we go a lousy candidate , the only one bad enough to lose to Trump and who even after being accused of being dishonest took illegal info on questions for the 2nd debate as well as having her husband meet the prosecuting judge (AG) in a private illegal meeting, again mafia style in an attempt to poison justice,

Still you can blame. White men, women, Putin, millenials, lazy POC who lacked the right enthusiam as they had with Obama (the infinitely better candidate btw!!), Christians, the FBI, Julian Assange, wikileaks a biased media etc etc.

Sure, everyone except the corrupt DNC and Hillary are to blame for this right??? The mind boggles!
How very thoughtful of Jill Stein to collect $2 million for contesting the results in three states. Maybe we'll discover that Stein actually won in Michigan, Pennsylvania, and Wisconsin.

From Jill Stein 2016 site: "This is about more than the results of this one election. This is about protecting our democracy and ensuring that "We the People" can have confidence in reported results."

I don't find that unreasonable, and Dr. Stein is in touch with reality enough to know she didn't win. She knows this is about confidence in reported results, and with the recent Russian hacking events, a nice paper trail recount would help. I donated to the recount effort, and apparently so did a lot of other people in a very short time frame. My husband and I lived and voted in Florida for the 2000 election, my husband voted on a black box machine that kept flipping his Gore choice to Bush on the screen. The poll workers would not let him switch to another machine, insisted he vote on that machine even though it still kept saying W, and refused to take that machine out of commission.

So yeah it matters. Maybe this recount won't be shut down like in 2000. It is worth the money, time and effort to a lot of people like myself who know voting machines and systems can and do fail, and can be hacked. Let's find out.
This is a perversely odd comment. Irony wrapped in a mind that misses the point.
Stein cares about truth
Clinton, I took Don Trump's attacks on you as attacks on me. I'm not tired, why are you? I will fight until I die. It is my duty.
Way to go, Pat.

She's not fighting because she probably made a "deal" with the "artful dealmaker" to shut her covert pandora's box of problems regarding the Clinton foundation.  I'm no Trump fan, but Ms. Hillary has very quietly accepted to go away...very strange behavior for such an ambitious woman.

Wouldn't you be tired if you just run the same campaign as she just did?  Are you some kind of superman robot?  Or rather a bitter anti Hillary fiend?  Obviously you're not going to "fight till you die", it's just something you threw out to feel superior?  Or perhaps, consciously or unconsciously, you're a Trump's shill?
It's $2.5m to ensure confidence in America's election process. They can gladly waste my money and time. As for the rest sure, you're correct.

When the vote is this close and the popular vote goes the way it is going, there should be an automatic recount that is triggered by law, not by any candidate requesting it. And for heaven's sake, why do we even have electronic voting that can't even be checked later? And why are those machines not secured better? There was hacking into regional voting machines before this election, probably from Russia. Why are voting machines not treated like things needing utmost security?
Well said... The election was rigged.

You know exactly why! It was well publicized when these machines came on the market. They were designed a recount was not possible and some deliberately altered picks. The manufacturers have close ties to the Rs.

Americans don't love the Republic or democracy - unless they win.

The machines are not secure because they are gotten from a company owned by Soros or a friend of his so guess whose side would most likely benefit from tampering- and while they are worried about recounting the paper  how about the ones where people acctully saw their vote for Trump changed to Clinton till they reported it and how many did not notice. Sorry as for popular vote unless they can verify that all of those are legal citizens  it is not pertinent  and going by popular vote would jsut do what the fathers meant to avoid  heavy population areas ruling or misruling those with smaller populations  result would be whole nation sanctuary for illegals and citizens paying for everything for nothing
Yes - the Electoral College amounts to rigging.

Here's the strategy behind this - it's a long shot but perhaps the only one that has any chance to succeed. Put into question the outcome of the election in sufficient close-count states to make it impossible to make the Constitution's deadline for the Electoral College to meet and cast their votes. Remember, these are based on the election results in each state with little chance to persuade electors to switch. Without a result from the EC, the decision as to President falls to the House of Representatives. Sure, it's Republican controlled but they aren't bound in any particular way to the election vote count at state level and some might be persuaded by the national popular vote - it would not take all that many Republican "defections" to get a majority assuming the Democrats can actually stick together. And there is where the pressure will be applied to go against allowing Donald Trump to move into the White House despite the EC results - all constitutional.

Take that, Founding Fathers!
Interesting.  Hadn't thought of this.  But we may soon find out if you're right.
And suppose the House selects someone you like less than Trump. Then what?
And we get Pence?

That or he leveraged popular prejudices and the nation's economic vulnerabilities to get into office. Now that he's in, it appears he will follow through on little of what he promised, which could be a good thing.  But if he stands for nothing, we should ask: why did he run for office? Many have suggested it was for personal gain.

Right Wingers have no interest or incentive to maintain or build a well-funded and effective public education that is available to all. After all, research confirms that that more education a person has, the more likely that they will have a generally Liberal worldview. Why would the Republicans put money into something that would clearly decrease their voter base?
I have the impression that the commenter here does not know the difference between Beijing dialect and Mandarin spoken with a Beijing accent.

I second that emotion!

I have been insulted, physically assaulted (woman-slammed from behind in an independent bookstore right off my feet; revenge against the patriarchy?!), and requested by a woman not to go into the locker room of my community swimming pool where I swim laps three times a week because, "As far as I'm concerned, every man is a rapist or molester" when her young son was apparently in there.

Needless to say, I SHOULD be a natural ally of all causes and folks progressive, but this nonsense has driven me to a dark place of rejection of these people's "problems" which are imaginary anyway, as far as I'm concerned. I'm glad I got an education before the academic Maoists started the brainwashing.

Martin, Charles turned 87 Sunday. I think he wanted to stay longer today to celebrate but I had errands to run. Because of the Holiday, the Opera was shifted to Saturday. It's a five hour opera. He will be home at midnight, get up at 6 for Mass and I will pick him up at 11. One of us will croak one of these days and my money isn't on him.

I find it strange that I need to point out that the days of all white worker shops ended a half century ago. Hard working minorities work, or worked, shoulder to shoulder with whites, and when manufacturing jobs disappeared, the economic loss was "equal opportunity".

Why is it assumed that everyone concerned about manufacturing job losses is a white non college graduate, probably male? Over my working career, which started in the mid 1960s, I saw minorities on the production line everywhere. And when jobs were lost, those minorities also lost them. There is some kind of reverse perverse political correctness in assuming that only white blue collar workers have been affected.

And when I hear about non college graduate voters, it always sounds like code words for "stupid" voters. Well, some of the stupidest people I have ever encountered are those with advanced degrees and privileged. Not all, but some. Such as those $800 a seat theater goers who decide to boo the Vice President elect and his family, before they have even taken office. If they won't respect the man, they should at least show some respect for the office.

I agree.

It´s not a "white blue collar workers" issue. All are affected by the same problems. Only the expression of response is different.

- many white blue collar workers went to the ballot and did not vote for Dems but for Mr. Trump
- many black (and other minority-) blue collar workers stayed at home so they did not vote for Dems also.

Additionally:

- The voters who only voted for HRC to avoid Mr. Trump and his supporters have NOT voted FOR Dems but AGAINST Mr. Trump and/or GOP.

So the discussion focussed on "wbcw" is twisted and the problems of Dem´s are different and much bigger than they admit.

The only reason "Identy Politics" is such a big issue is because
- discussion get so arcane that nobody can follow but a very special campus crowd in some regions in USA
- solving real problems is neglected for debating this isssue all the time
- focussing on this diverts all political processes from substantive issues so this cannot be tackled,
- all other social groups don´t see any use to join this kind of talks
- many resources required to fix real problems are wasted for more or less ideologic arguing
- most people abroad - as me- agree that you cannot talk with American academics in a straight way anymore,
- many real global issues requiring cooperation with American academics stay unfixed.

There´s nothing wrong with "PI."

But it´s a "one among other" issue that may not end up to alienation of other social groups and to political self-paralysis.

I think the real problem is lack of work. If high school students saw that there would be a path to a decent life without having a college degree they would be more likely to graduate - for example, apprenticeship programs, internships with local companies and so on. When people of different 'identities' work together they would get to know each other and see how much we all have in common.

Does progress produce any meaningful rhetoric - meaningful enough to endure the coming waves of change?

Is our destiny is to be mute problem solvers? In that case, I guess language would not matter enough that we should care about restricting it, for the sake of others' feelings.

Scrapiron, I'm also a long-time (25+ years) homeschool parent and active part of the self-directed learning community, and where I live, as well as in the many places I've traveled and met other homeschool families, the norm is the diametric opposite of what you describe. I'm sorry to hear about kids tethered to computers, doing rote lessons there--that sounds like they (or their parents?) may be attempting to duplicate a typical public-school curriculum approach at home, which is the antithesis of what every homeschool family I've met has done with the ever-expanding world of options available to them, even those with limited financial resources.

Gulati's job is to manage. What he's doing instead is shuffling deck chairs on the Titanic. The reason Bruce Arena lost his job after 2006 was that he was exposed as being completely out of his depth against good international competition. Managing in a second-tier league is not likely to have sharpened his skills.

At this stage, the USMNT should not have a domestic-based manager. It's just that simple. Bob Bradley, who was also overmatched internationally, is getting his lunch eaten for him in the Premier League and he was supposedly the great American hope.

It's the world's game. We need to see it like the world does. Right now, there isn't an American manager who can really do that.

Then how do you explain Arena's run to the quarterfinals at the Japan World Cup?

Bradley has inherited a lousy team. He took over a win less Swansea team in early October. Also how do you explain Bradley leading the USMNT to the final of the 2009 Confederations Cup (where we outplayed Brazil for most of the match)?

A few more things on Sunil Gulati:

1) In 1998, Gulati was one the driving forces behind U.S. Soccer’s Project 2010, a $50 million development initiative that was supposed be the road map to take Team USA to the pinnacle of the world’s most popular sport. “Winning the World Cup by 2010: Soccer’s Equivalent to the Apollo XI Moon Landing.” The document’s cover featured an astronaut on the Moon, American flag in one hand, the World Cup trophy in the other, an image that, like the report’s title, is even more laughable now than it was then.

1) Sunil repeatedly enabled Hope Solo through one embarrassment after another, is stuck in another ugly but avoidable labor dispute (and public relations disaster - 60 Minutes last week) with the only U.S. team that wins, the Women’s World Cup champions, and has presided over the U.S. men’s failure to qualify for the past two Olympic Games or get past the second round at the past three World Cups.

2) Gulati's best friend is/was Chuck Blazer, but knew nothing of the bribes and corruption within CONCACAF (during his 15 year association with Blazer and CONCACAF during the scandal), was unwilling to talk to Congress during their investigation of the matter, yet got himself onto FIFA’s Executive Committee in 2013 (with then mafioso boss Sepp Blatter ).

4) As a FIFA EXCO member Sunil earns $300K per year for 5 meetings worth of work. If you serve 5 years there's a lifetime pension of over $100K per year.
